longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To amend and consolidate the law relating to the constitution, jurisdiction, practice and powers of the High Court and the administration of justice therein and for matters ancillary thereto and connected therewith.

editorialNote.content: The title of this Ordinance was amended from “Supreme Court Ordinance” to “High Court Ordinance” — see 25 of 1998 s. 2.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.text: This Ordinance may be cited as the High Court Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—

def.name: Appeal
def.leadIn: appeal (上訴) in the context of appeals to the Court of Appeal in its civil jurisdiction includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for a new trial; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application to set aside a verdict, finding or judgment in any cause or matter in the Court of First Instance which has been tried, or in which any issue has been tried, by a jury; (Added 52 of 1987 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.def: cause (訟案) means any action or any criminal proceeding; (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 2)
Court of First Instance (原訟法庭) means the Court of First Instance of the High Court; (Added 25 of 1998 s. 2)
defendant (被告人) includes any person served with any writ of summons or process, or served with notice of, or entitled to attend, any proceedings;
deputy judge (暫委法官) means a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance appointed under section 10(1); (Added 49 of 1983 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
detention (羈留) includes every form of restraint of liberty of the person; (Added 95 of 1997 s. 2)
Government stock (政府證券) means any stock issued by the Government or any funds of or annuity granted by the Government; (Added 52 of 1987 s. 2)
judgment (判決) includes decree;

Justice of Appeal (上訴法庭法官) includes a judge of the Court of First Instance acting as an additional judge of the Court of Appeal under section 5(2); (Added 52 of 1987 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 21 of 2020 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: land covered by water;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any estate, right, interest or easement in or over any land; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: things attached to land or permanently fastened to anything attached to land; (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 2)

section.def: Master (聆案官) has the meaning given to it by sections 37, 37AC, 37A and 37B; (Added 52 of 1987 s. 2. Amended 1 of 1997 s. 3; 10 of 2005 s. 164)

plaintiff (原告人) includes every person asking any relief (otherwise than by way of counter-claim as a defendant) against any other person by any form of proceeding, whether the proceeding is by action, suit, petition, motion, summons or otherwise;
prescribed (訂明) means prescribed by rules of court;
recorder (特委法官) means a recorder of the Court of First Instance appointed under section 6A; (Added 80 of 1994 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Registrar (司法常務官) means the Registrar of the High Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Registry (登記處) means any Registry of the High Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
writ of habeas corpus (人身保護令狀) means a writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum. (Added 95 of 1997 s. 2)
section.sourceNote: (Amended 49 of 1983 s. 2; 95 of 1997 s. 2; 25 of 1998 s. 2; Amended E.R. 1 of 2017)

section.name: s3
section.heading: High Court

subsection.content: There shall be a High Court of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region consisting of the Court of First Instance and the Court of Appeal.
Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the High Court shall be a court of unlimited civil and criminal jurisdiction.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Constitution of Court of First Instance

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge of the High Court; (Amended 79 of 1995 s. 50)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such judges as the Governor may appoint; (Amended 80 of 1994 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: such recorders as the Governor may appoint; and (Added 80 of 1994 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: such deputy judges as the Chief Justice may appoint. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 4)

subsection.content: A Justice of Appeal may act as a judge of the Court of First Instance whenever the business of the Court of First Instance so requires, in which case he shall have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of such a judge. (Amended 21 of 2020 s. 4)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Constitution of Court of Appeal

subsection.leadIn: The Court of Appeal shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge of the High Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such Justices of Appeal as the Governor may appoint.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Chief Judge of the High Court may appoint one or more of the Justices of Appeal as vice-presidents of the Court of Appeal. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 5)

A judge of the Court of First Instance may, on the request of the Chief Justice, act as an additional judge of the Court of Appeal, in which case he shall have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of a judge of the Court of Appeal. (Amended 21 of 2020 s. 5)

The Chief Judge of the High Court shall be the president of the Court of Appeal and, in his absence for any cause, the presidency shall be determined in accordance with the order of precedence prescribed in section 7.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Appointment of judges

subsection.leadIn: A judge of the High Court, other than— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judge appointed under section 8(1) or (2); (Amended 80 of 1994 s. 4)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: a recorder; (Added 80 of 1994 s. 4. Amended 26 of 1997 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a deputy judge; and (Amended 49 of 1983 s. 3; 26 of 1997 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a judge appointed under section 11A(3)(a), (Added 26 of 1997 s. 2)

subsection.continued: shall be appointed by Letters Patent under the Public Seal by the Governor, in accordance with such instructions as the Governor may receive through a Secretary of State.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Appointment of recorders

subsection.content: The Governor may appoint a person who is eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court under section 9(1) or (1A), to be a recorder of the Court of First Instance for such period as may be specified in the instrument by which the appointment is made. (Amended 1 of 1997 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: An appointment made under subsection (1) shall be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of the first appointment of a person as a recorder, by Letters Patent under the Public Seal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a reappointment or subsequent appointment of a person who has previously been appointed, by such other instrument under the hand of the Governor as the Governor thinks fit.

subsection.content: A recorder shall have and may exercise all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges and shall have and perform all the duties of a judge of the Court of First Instance, and any reference in any law to such a judge shall be construed accordingly.

section.name: s6B
section.heading: Appointment of judges and recorders may be retrospective

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), any appointment made under section 6(1) or 6A(1) may be given effect from a date anterior to that of the Letters Patent by which it is made.

Nothing in subsection (1) shall be deemed to authorize the discharge of any judicial functions by any person so appointed before the date of the Letters Patent or before the requirements of section 17 of the Oaths and Declarations Ordinance (Cap. 11) have been fulfilled.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Precedence

subsection.leadIn: The judges of the High Court shall take precedence in the following order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge of the High Court; (Amended 79 of 1995 s. 50)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: the vice-presidents of the Court of Appeal who among themselves shall rank according to the priority of their respective appointments as vice-presidents; (Added 52 of 1987 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Justices of Appeal (other than vice-presidents), who among themselves shall rank according to the priority of their respective appointments; (Amended 52 of 1987 s. 6)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the judges of the Court of First Instance, who among themselves shall rank according to the priority of their respective appointments;

content.leadIn: the recorders of the Court of First Instance, who among themselves shall rank according to the priority of their respective appointments:
content.proviso: Provided that, where the Governor is of the opinion that there are sufficient reasons for so doing, he may determine the precedence of recorders irrespective of the priority of their appointments; (Added 80 of 1994 s. 6)

content.leadIn: deputy judges, who among themselves shall rank according to the priority of their respective appointments:
content.proviso: Provided that, where the Governor is of the opinion that there are sufficient reasons for so doing, he may determine the precedence of deputy judges irrespective of the priority of their appointments. (Amended 49 of 1983 s. 4)

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (1)(b) and (c), where the Secretary of State is of the opinion that there are sufficient reasons for so doing, he may determine the precedence of the Justices of Appeal or the judges of the Court of First Instance, as the case may be, irrespective of the priority of their appointments.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Acting appointments

subsection.content: If the office of Chief Judge of the High Court or any Justice of Appeal becomes vacant, by death or otherwise, the Governor may appoint another person, who is eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court under section 9, to act in such office until the vacancy therein is filled.

If the Chief Judge of the High Court or a Justice of Appeal is temporarily ill or absent, the Governor may appoint another person, who is eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court under section 9, to act in his office until he resumes the duties thereof.
Any appointment made under subsection (1) or (2) may be given effect from a date anterior to that of the instrument by which it is made. (Added 80 of 1994 s. 7)

section.name: s9
section.heading: Professional qualifications of judges

subsection.leadIn: A person shall be eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court if— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is qualified to practise as a barrister or advocate in a court in Hong Kong or any other common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters; or (Amended 14 of 1997 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is qualified as mentioned in paragraph (a) and prior thereto was qualified to practise as a solicitor in such a court,

subsection.continued: and, in either case, he has for at least 10 years practised as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in such a court.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: A person shall also be eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court if he is qualified to practise as a solicitor of the High Court and has for at least 10 years practised as such. (Added 52 of 1995 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A person shall also be eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court if— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is qualified to practise as a barrister or advocate in a court in Hong Kong or any other common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters; or (Amended 14 of 1997 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is qualified as mentioned in paragraph (a) and prior thereto was qualified to practise as a solicitor in such a court,

subsection.continued: and, in either case, he has, subject to subsection (3), for at least 10 years—

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: been a District Judge appointed in accordance with section 4 or 7 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);

paragraph.name: iva
paragraph.content: been the Registrar of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal appointed in accordance with section 42 of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484); (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: ivb
paragraph.content: been the Registrar or a senior deputy registrar, deputy registrar or assistant registrar appointed in accordance with section 37; (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: ivc
paragraph.content: been the Registrar of the District Court or a deputy registrar or assistant registrar of the District Court, appointed in accordance with section 14 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336); (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: been a permanent magistrate appointed in accordance with section 5 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227);

paragraph.name: va
paragraph.content: been a coroner appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Coroners Ordinance (Cap. 504); (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: vb
paragraph.content: been an adjudicator appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Small Claims Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 338); (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: vc
paragraph.content: been a presiding officer appointed in accordance with section 4 of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25); (Added 10 of 2005 s. 132)

paragraph.name: vi
paragraph.content: been a legal officer as defined in section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87);

paragraph.name: viii
paragraph.content: been the Director of Legal Aid or a Deputy Director of Legal Aid, Assistant Director of Legal Aid or Legal Aid Officer, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91); (Added 50 of 1976 s. 2. Amended 24 of 1983 s. 7; 39 of 1992 s. 8; 60 of 1992 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ix
paragraph.content: been the Official Receiver or an Assistant Official Receiver (Legal), Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 75 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Added 39 of 1992 s. 8. Amended 60 of 1992 s. 3; 68 of 1995 s. 17)

paragraph.name: x
paragraph.content: been the Director of Intellectual Property or a Deputy Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Director of Intellectual Property, Assistant Principal Solicitor, Senior Solicitor or Solicitor, appointed in accordance with section 3 of the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412). (Added 60 of 1992 s. 3. Amended 26 of 2012 s. 34)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: A person shall also be eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court if— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is a solicitor of a court in Hong Kong or any other common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters; (Amended 14 of 1997 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is and has been for the previous 2 years at least, and in aggregate for at least 5 years, employed in the service of the Crown in Hong Kong on judicial or legal work; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: he has, subject to subsection (4), for at least 10 years either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: practised as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in such a court; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: been employed in such service as is described in paragraph (b). (Added 44 of 1982 s. 2)

subsection.content: For the purposes of calculating the period of 10 years referred to in subsection (2), periods of less than 10 years falling within any of paragraphs (iv) to (x) of that subsection may be combined, and there may be included in such period, any period of practice as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in any of the courts referred to in subsection (2)(a). (Amended 50 of 1976 s. 2; 39 of 1992 s. 8; 60 of 1992 s. 3; 14 of 1997 s. 2)

For the purposes of calculating the period of 10 years referred to in subsection (2A)(c) there may be included any period of less than 10 years falling within any of paragraphs (iv) to (x) of subsection (2), and periods of less than 10 years falling within subparagraphs (i) and (ii) of subsection (2A)(c) may be combined. (Added 44 of 1982 s. 2. Amended 39 of 1992 s. 8; 60 of 1992 s. 3; 14 of 1997 s. 2)

For the purposes of calculating the period of 10 years under subsection (2), periods served in an office specified in Part I of the First Schedule to the repealed Registrar General (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 100) may be taken into account notwithstanding the repeal of that Ordinance. (Added 8 of 1993 s. 6)

section.name: s10
section.heading: Appointment of deputy judges

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may appoint a person, who is eligible to be appointed to be a judge of the High Court under section 9, to be a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance if— (Amended 44 of 1982 s. 3; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the office of any judge of the Court of First Instance becomes vacant for any reason; or (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he considers that the interests of the administration of justice require that a deputy judge should be appointed temporarily.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1B), any appointment made under subsection (1) may be given effect from a date anterior to that of the instrument by which it is made. (Added 80 of 1994 s. 8)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: Nothing in subsection (1A) shall be deemed to authorize the discharge of any judicial functions by any person so appointed before the date of the instrument or before the requirements of section 17 of the Oaths and Declarations Ordinance (Cap. 11) have been fulfilled. (Added 80 of 1994 s. 8)

Subject to the terms of his appointment, a deputy judge shall have and may exercise all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges and shall have and perform all the duties of a judge of the Court of First Instance, and any reference in any law to such a judge shall be construed accordingly. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the powers conferred on him by subsection (1), the Chief Justice may appoint a deputy judge under that subsection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of a specified case or class of cases only; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a specified period only.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (2), the Chief Justice may terminate the appointment of a deputy judge at any time.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Powers of recorders and deputy judges in cases which are part-heard on termination of appointment
section.text: If the hearing of any proceedings before a recorder or deputy judge is adjourned or if he reserves judgment in any proceedings, the recorder or deputy judge shall have power to resume the hearing and determine the proceedings or deliver judgment, notwithstanding that his appointment as a recorder or deputy judge has expired or has been terminated.

section.name: s11AA
section.heading: Interpretation of this section and sections 11A and 11B
section.leadIn: In this section and sections 11A and 11B—
section.def: Circular (《通告》) means a Circular issued by the Chief Justice on the details of the retirement age (extension) arrangement for judicial officers engaged on terms that do not attract pension benefits under the Pension Benefits (Judicial Officers) Ordinance (Cap. 401);

retirement age (extension) arrangement (退休年齡(延展)安排) means the arrangements in relation to the extension of the ages of retirement and terms of office for judicial officers as provided by the amendments contained in the Judicial Officers (Extension of Retirement Age) (Amendment) Ordinance 2019 (10 of 2019).

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Term of office of judges

subsection.content: A judge of the High Court must vacate his office when he attains the retirement age.

Notwithstanding the fact that he has attained the retirement age, a person holding the office of a judge of the High Court may continue in office for so long after attaining the retirement age as may be necessary to enable him to deliver judgment or to do any other thing in relation to proceedings that were commenced before him before he attained that age.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who has attained the age of 70 years may be appointed to be a judge of the High Court (whether or not the person has previously held office as such) for a specified period or periods not exceeding 5 years in the aggregate by the Chief Executive acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission; and (Replaced 10 of 2019 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the term of office of a judge of the High Court (other than a person appointed to be a judge under paragraph (a)) may be extended for a specified period or periods not exceeding 5 years in the aggregate by the Chief Executive acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission,

subsection.continued: and in any such case the judge is accordingly to be regarded as having attained the retirement age at the expiration of the specified period or periods.

subsection.content: A judge of the High Court may at any time resign his office by notice in writing addressed to the Chief Executive.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: RetirementAge
def.leadIn: retirement age (退休年齡), for a judge of the High Court, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unless paragraph (b) applies—the age of 70 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the judge could have opted for the retirement age (extension) arrangement pursuant to section 11A of the Pension Benefits (Judicial Officers) Ordinance (Cap. 401) or the Circular, and has not so opted—the age of 65 years. (Replaced 10 of 2019 s. 4)

section.sourceNote: (Added 26 of 1997 s. 3. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 10 of 2019 s. 4)

section.name: s11B
section.heading: Transitional provisions relating to retirement age (extension) arrangement

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: SpecifiedJudge
def.leadIn: specified judge (指明法官) means a judge of the High Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whose term of office has been extended under section 11A(3)(b) before the commencement date* of the Judicial Officers (Extension of Retirement Age) (Amendment) Ordinance 2019 (10 of 2019); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who has opted for the retirement age (extension) arrangement pursuant to section 11A of the Pension Benefits (Judicial Officers) Ordinance (Cap. 401) or the Circular.

subsection.content: If, but for this section, the extended term of office of a specified judge would have expired before the judge attains the age of 70 years, the judge’s term of office is extended to the date immediately before the judge attains the age of 70 years.

When a specified judge attains the age of 70 years, the judge’s term of office may be further extended under section 11A(3)(b) for a specified period or periods not exceeding 5 years in the aggregate, as if the judge’s term of office had not previously been extended.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Jurisdiction of Court of First Instance

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance shall be a superior court of record.

subsection.leadIn: The civil jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: original jurisdiction and authority of a like nature and extent as that held and exercised by the Chancery, Family and Queen’s Bench Divisions of the High Court of Justice in England; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other jurisdiction, whether original or appellate jurisdiction, conferred on it by any law.

subsection.leadIn: The criminal jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: original jurisdiction of a like nature and extent as that held and exercised in criminal matters by the High Court of Justice and the Crown Court in England respectively; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other jurisdiction, whether original or appellate jurisdiction, conferred on it by any law.

section.name: s12A
section.heading: Admiralty jurisdiction of Court of First Instance

subsection.leadIn: The Admiralty jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance shall consist of— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: jurisdiction to hear and determine any of the questions and claims mentioned in subsection (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: jurisdiction in relation to any of the proceedings mentioned in subsection (3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other Admiralty jurisdiction which it had immediately before the commencement of the Supreme Court (Amendment) Ordinance 1989 (3 of 1989).

subsection.leadIn: The questions and claims referred to in subsection (1)(a) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any claim to the possession or ownership of a ship or to the ownership of any share therein;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any question arising between the co-owners of a ship as to possession, employment or earnings of that ship;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of a mortgage of or charge on a ship or any share therein;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any claim for damage received by a ship;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any claim for damage done by a ship;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: any claim for loss of life or personal injury sustained in consequence of any defect in a ship or in her apparel or equipment, or in consequence of the wrongful act, neglect or default of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the owners, charterers or persons in possession or control of a ship; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the master or crew of a ship, or any other person for whose wrongful acts, neglects or defaults the owners, charterers or persons in possession or control of a ship are responsible,

paragraph.continued: being an act, neglect or default in the navigation or management of the ship, in the loading, carriage or discharge of goods on, in or from the ship, or in the embarkation, carriage or disembarkation of persons on, in or from the ship;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any claim for loss of or damage to goods carried in a ship;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: any claim arising out of any agreement relating to the carriage of goods in a ship or to the use or hire of a ship;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: any claim—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under the Salvage Convention 1989;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under any contract for or in relation to salvage services; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the nature of salvage not falling within subparagraph (i) or (ii);

paragraph.continued: or any corresponding claim in connection with an aircraft; (Replaced 35 of 1997 s. 9)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: any claim in the nature of towage in respect of a ship or an aircraft;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: any claim in the nature of pilotage in respect of a ship or an aircraft;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of goods or materials supplied to a ship for her operation or maintenance;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of the construction, repair or equipment of a ship or in respect of dock charges or dues;

paragraph.name: n
o
paragraph.content: any claim by a master, shipper, charterer or agent in respect of disbursements made on account of a ship;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: any claim arising out of an act which is or is claimed to be a general average act;

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: any claim arising out of bottomry;

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: any claim for the forfeiture or condemnation of a ship or of goods which are being or have been carried, or have been attempted to be carried, in a ship, or for the restoration of a ship or any such goods after seizure, or for droits of Admiralty;

paragraph.name: s
paragraph.content: any claim arising under section 7 of the Merchant Shipping (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 413). (Replaced 37 of 1990 s. 12(2))

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings referred to in subsection (1)(b) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any application to the Court of First Instance under— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Liability and Compensation for Oil Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 414); (Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415); (Replaced 74 of 1990 s. 104(3). Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30; 24 of 2005 s. 55)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Limitation of Shipowners Liability) Ordinance (Cap. 434); (Added 55 of 1993 s. 30. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 55; 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); or (Added 24 of 2005 s. 55. Amended 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: the Bunker Oil Pollution (Liability and Compensation) Ordinance (Cap. 605); (Added 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any action to enforce a claim for damage, loss of life or personal injury arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a collision between ships;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the carrying out of or omission to carry out a manoeuvre in the case of 1 or more of 2 or more ships; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: non-compliance, on the part of 1 or more of 2 or more ships, with the collision regulations;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any action by shipowners or other persons under—

subparagraph.name: i
iii
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369); (Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Liability and Compensation for Oil Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 414); (Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30; 24 of 2005 s. 55)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Limitation of Shipowners Liability) Ordinance (Cap. 434); (Added 55 of 1993 s. 30. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 55; 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); or (Added 24 of 2005 s. 55. Amended 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the Bunker Oil Pollution (Liability and Compensation) Ordinance (Cap. 605), (Added 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.continued: for the limitation of the amount of their liability in connection with a ship or other property. (Replaced 38 of 1990 Sch. 2)

subsection.content: The jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance under subsection (2)(b) includes power to settle any account outstanding and unsettled between the parties in relation to the ship, and to direct that the ship, or any share thereof, shall be sold, and to make such other order as the court thinks fit. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2)(e) extends to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of a liability incurred under Part II of the Merchant Shipping (Liability and Compensation for Oil Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 414); (Amended 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of a liability incurred by the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund under Part III of that Ordinance; and (Replaced 38 of 1990 Sch. 2. Amended 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any claim in respect of a liability incurred under section 5 of the Bunker Oil Pollution (Liability and Compensation) Ordinance (Cap. 605). (Added 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (2)(i)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: the Salvage Convention 1989 (1989年救助公約) means the International Convention on Salvage 1989 as it has effect under section 9 of the Merchant Shipping (Collision Damage Liability and Salvage) Ordinance (Cap. 508);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reference to salvage services includes services rendered in saving life from a ship and the reference to any claim under any contract for or in relation to salvage services includes any claim arising out of such a contract whether or not arising during the provision of the services;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reference to a corresponding claim in connection with an aircraft is a reference to any claim corresponding to any claim mentioned in subsection (2)(i)(i) or (ii) which is available under section 9 of the Civil Aviation Ordinance (Cap. 448). (Replaced 35 of 1997 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: Subsections (1) to (6) apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to all ships or aircraft, whether British or not and whether registered or not and wherever the residence or domicile of their owners may be;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to all claims, wherever arising (including, in the case of cargo or wreck salvage, claims in respect of cargo or wreck found on land); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: so far as they relate to mortgages and charges, to all mortgages or charges, whether registered or not and whether legal or equitable, including mortgages and charges created under foreign law.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in subsection (7) shall be construed as extending the cases in which money or property is recoverable under any of the provisions of—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281);

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) Ordinance (Cap. 478); (Added 44 of 1995 s. 143)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Liability and Compensation for Oil Pollution) Ordinance (Cap. 414); (Replaced 38 of 1990 Sch 2. Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415); (Added 74 of 1990 s. 104(3). Amended 55 of 1993 s. 30; 24 of 2005 s. 55)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Limitation of Shipowners Liability) Ordinance (Cap. 434); (Added 55 of 1993 s. 30. Amended 24 of 2005 s. 55; 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); or (Added 24 of 2005 s. 55. Amended 14 of 2009 s. 34)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the Bunker Oil Pollution (Liability and Compensation) Ordinance (Cap. 605). (Added 14 of 2009 s. 34)

subsection.name: a
subsection.content: in relation to the Merchant Shipping Act 1894, Part 3 of Schedule 5 to Cap. 415 and s. 1 of Schedule 2 to Cap. 508;

subsection.name: b
subsection.content: in relation to the Merchant Shipping Acts 1894 to 1979, s. 117 of Cap. 281, s. 103 of Cap. 415 and s. 142 of Cap. 478.

section.name: s12B
section.heading: Mode of exercise of Admiralty jurisdiction

subsection.content: Subject to section 12C an action in personam may be brought in the Court of First Instance in all cases within the Admiralty jurisdiction of that court.

In the case of any such claim as is mentioned in section 12A(2)(a), (c) or (r) or any such question as is mentioned in section 12A(2)(b), an action in rem may be brought in the Court of First Instance against the ship or property in connection with which the claim or question arises and such action shall be deemed to be brought by and upon the issue of the writ in rem.

In any case in which there is a maritime lien or other charge on any ship, aircraft or other property for the amount claimed, an action in rem may be brought in the Court of First Instance against that ship, aircraft or property.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of any such claim as is mentioned in section 12A(2)(e) to (q), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claim arises in connection with a ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who would be liable on the claim in an action in personam (the relevant person) was, when the cause of action arose, the owner or charterer of, or in possession or in control of, the ship,

subsection.continued: an action in rem may (whether or not the claim gives rise to a maritime lien on that ship) be brought in the Court of First Instance against—

paragraph.content: that ship, if at the time when the action is brought the relevant person is either the beneficial owner of that ship as respects all the shares in it or the charterer of it under a charter by demise; or
any other ship of which, at the time when the action is brought, the relevant person is the beneficial owner as respects all the shares in it.

subsection.content: In the case of a claim in the nature of towage or pilotage in respect of an aircraft, an action in rem may be brought in the Court of First Instance against that aircraft if, at the time when the action is brought, it is beneficially owned by the person who would be liable on the claim in an action in personam.

Where, in the exercise of its Admiralty jurisdiction, the Court of First Instance orders any ship, aircraft or other property to be sold, the court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine any question arising as to the title to the proceeds of sale.

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may order a stay of Admiralty proceedings under section 20 of the Arbitration Ordinance (Cap. 609), subject to any conditions that it may impose, including the making of an order for the property arrested or the bail or security given in those proceedings to be retained as security for the satisfaction of any award made in the arbitration. (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

In determining for the purposes of subsections (4) and (5) whether a person would be liable on a claim in an action in personam it shall be assumed that he has his habitual residence or a place of business within Hong Kong.

Where, as regards any such claim as is mentioned in section 12A(2)(e) to (q), a ship has been served with a writ or arrested in an action in rem brought to enforce that claim, no other ship may be served with a writ or arrested in that or any other action in rem brought to enforce that claim; but this subsection does not prevent the issue, in respect of any one such claim, of a writ naming more than 1 ship or of 2 or more writs each naming a different ship.

section.name: s12C
section.heading: Restrictions on entertainment of actions in personam in collision and other similar cases

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to any claim for damage, loss of life or personal injury arising out of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a collision between ships;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the carrying out of, or omission to carry out, a manoeuvre in the case of 1 or more of 2 or more ships; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: non-compliance, on the part of 1 or more of 2 or more ships, with the collision regulations.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not entertain any action in personam to enforce a claim to which this section applies unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant has his habitual residence or a place of business in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the cause of action arose within the waters of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an action arising out of the same incident or series of incidents is proceeding in the court or has been heard and determined in the court.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance shall not entertain any action in personam to enforce a claim to which this section applies until any proceedings previously brought by the plaintiff in any court outside Hong Kong against the same defendant in respect of the same incident or series of incidents have been discontinued or otherwise come to an end.

Subsections (2) and (3) shall apply to counterclaims (except counterclaims in proceedings arising out of the same incident or series of incidents) as they apply to actions, the references to the plaintiff and the defendant being for this purpose read as references to the plaintiff on the counterclaim and the defendant to the counterclaim respectively.
Subsections (2) and (3) shall not apply to any action or counterclaim if the defendant thereto submits or has agreed to submit to the jurisdiction of the court.

Subject to subsection (3), the Court of First Instance shall have jurisdiction to entertain an action in personam to enforce a claim to which this section applies whenever any of the conditions specified in subsection (2)(a) to (c) is satisfied, and the rules of court relating to the service of process outside the jurisdiction shall make such provision as may appear to the Rules Committee constituted under section 55 to be appropriate having regard to the provisions of this subsection.

Nothing in this section shall prevent an action which is brought in accordance with the provisions of this section in the Court of First Instance being transferred, in accordance with the enactments in that behalf, to some other court.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that this section applies in relation to the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance not being Admiralty jurisdiction as well as in relation to its Admiralty jurisdiction.

section.name: s12D
section.heading: Court of First Instance not to have jurisdiction in cases within Rhine Navigation Convention
section.text: The Court of First Instance shall not have jurisdiction to determine any claim or question certified by the Governor to be a claim or question which under the Rhine Navigation Convention, falls to be determined in accordance with the provisions of that Convention; and any proceedings to enforce such a claim which are commenced in the Court of First Instance shall be set aside.

section.name: s12E
section.heading: Supplementary provisions as to Admiralty jurisdiction

subsection.leadIn: In sections 12A to 12D and this section, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: collision regulations (碰撞規例) means regulations made or deemed to have been made under Part IX of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369);
goods (貨物) includes baggage;

hovercraft (氣墊船) means a vehicle designed to be supported when in motion wholly, or partly, by air expelled from the vehicle to form a cushion of which the boundaries include the ground, water or other surface beneath the vehicle;
Rhine Navigation Convention (《萊茵河航行公約》) means the Convention of 7 October 1868 as revised by any subsequent convention;
ship (船舶) includes any description of vessel used in navigation and (except in subsection (2)(c) of this section) includes, subject to any regulations made by the Governor, a hovercraft;
towage (拖曳) and pilotage (領港) in relation to an aircraft, mean towage and pilotage while the aircraft is waterborne.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in sections 12A to 12D shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be construed as limiting the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance to refuse to entertain an action for wages by the master or a member of the crew of a ship, not being a British ship or a ship registered in Hong Kong; (Amended 74 of 1990 s. 104(3); 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: affect the provisions of section 552 of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 (1894 c. 60 U.K.)# (power of a receiver of wreck to detain a ship in respect of a salvage claim) in its application to Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: authorize proceedings in rem in respect of any claim against the Crown, or the arrest, detention or sale of any of Her Majesty’s ships or Her Majesty’s aircraft or Her Majesty’s hovercraft, or, subject to any regulations made by the Governor, of any ship, aircraft, hovercraft, cargo or other property belonging to the Crown or the Government of Hong Kong.

subsection.content: Droits of Admiralty or droits of or forfeitures to the Crown condemned by the Court of First Instance shall become the property of the Government of Hong Kong and the Court of First Instance may of its own motion or upon application order that such property be sold and the proceeds paid into the general revenue. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Her Majesty’s hovercraft (女皇陛下的氣墊船) means hovercraft belonging to the Crown in right of Her Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom or Her Majesty’s Government in Hong Kong;
Her Majesty’s ships (女皇陛下的船舶) and Her Majesty’s aircraft (女皇陛下的航空器) have the meanings given by section 38(2) of the Crown Proceedings Act 1947 (1947 c. 44 U.K.).

subsection.name: a
b
subsection.content: in relation to the Merchant Shipping Acts 1894 to 1979, s. 117 of Cap. 281, s. 103 of Cap. 415 and s. 142 of Cap. 478.

section.name: s12F
section.heading: Transfer of proceedings to the Lands Tribunal
section.content: The Court of First Instance may, either of its own motion or on the application of any party, order at any stage the transfer to the Lands Tribunal of all or part of any action or proceedings before it which are within the jurisdiction of the Lands Tribunal.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Jurisdiction of Court of Appeal

subsection.content: The Court of Appeal shall be a superior court of record.

subsection.leadIn: The civil jurisdiction of the Court of Appeal shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appeals from any judgment or order of the Court of First Instance in any civil cause or matter; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: appeals under section 63 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other jurisdiction conferred on it by any law.

subsection.leadIn: The criminal jurisdiction of the Court of Appeal shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appeals from the Court of First Instance or District Court under Part IV of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221); (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: appeals from a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance given or made in the exercise of the powers conferred on it under section 21I(1) and relating to a criminal cause or matter; (Added 2 of 1993 s. 3. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: the consideration of—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: references by the Secretary for Justice of questions of law under section 81D of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221); (Replaced 20 of 1979 s. 10. Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: appeals by way of case stated from the District Court under section 84 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336); and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other jurisdiction conferred on it by any law.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of and incidental to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the hearing and determination of any appeal to the Court of Appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amendment, execution and enforcement of any judgment or order made on such an appeal,

subsection.continued: the Court of Appeal shall have all the authority and jurisdiction of the court or tribunal from which the appeal was brought. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 9) [cf. 1981 c. 54 s. 15 U.K.]

subsection.content: Any provision in this or any other Ordinance which authorizes or requires the taking of any steps for the execution or enforcement of a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance applies in relation to a judgment or order of the Court of Appeal as it applies in relation to a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 9. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s14
section.heading: Appeals in civil matters

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3) and section 14AA, an appeal shall lie as of right to the Court of Appeal from every judgment or order of the Court of First Instance in any civil cause or matter. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 3 of 2008 s. 24)

subsection.leadIn: No appeal shall lie—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from an order of the Court of First Instance allowing an extension of time for appealing from a judgment or order; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2) [cf. 1925 c. 49 s. 31 U.K.]

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: from a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance, where it is provided by any Ordinance or by rules of court that the same is to be final; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: without the leave of the court or tribunal in question or of the Court of Appeal, from an order of the Court of First Instance or any other court or tribunal made with the consent of the parties or relating only to costs which are by law left to the discretion of the court or tribunal; (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 10. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2) [cf. 1981 c. 54 s. 18 U.K.]

paragraph.name: ea
paragraph.leadIn: except as provided by the Arbitration Ordinance (Cap. 609), from any judgment or order of the Court of First Instance— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under section 15(2) of that Ordinance refusing to direct an issue to be determined in accordance with an arbitration agreement; (Replaced 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under section 20(1) or (2) of that Ordinance refusing to refer the parties to arbitration; (Replaced 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: under section 60(1) of that Ordinance directing the sale of property; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: under section 81 of that Ordinance to set aside an arbitral award; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: under section 84, 87 or 92 of that Ordinance to grant or refuse leave to enforce an arbitral award; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: under section 3 of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance on a question of law arising in the course of arbitral proceedings; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: under section 4 of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance on a challenge against an arbitral award on the ground of serious irregularity; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: under section 5 or 6 of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance on a question of law arising out of an arbitral award; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: under section 7(2) and (3) of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance for an arbitral tribunal to state the reasons for its award and on related costs; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: x
subparagraph.content: under section 7(4) and (6) of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance on the giving of security for the costs of an application to challenge an arbitral tribunal or an appeal on a question of law arising out of an arbitral award, and for the money payable under the award pending the determination of the application or appeal; or (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

subparagraph.name: xi
subparagraph.content: under section 7(7) of Schedule 2 to that Ordinance to impose conditions on granting leave to appeal on a question of law arising out of an arbitral award; (Added 17 of 2010 s. 112)

paragraph.name: eb
paragraph.content: from a decision of the Court of First Instance in respect of which a certificate is granted under section 27C of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) and leave to appeal is granted under section 27D of that Ordinance in any proceedings; (Added 11 of 2002 s. 6)

content.leadIn: without the leave of the Court of First Instance or the Court of Appeal, from a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance given or made in summarily determining under rules of court any question at issue in interpleader proceedings: (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
content.proviso: Provided that this paragraph shall have no effect in relation to any interpleader issue which is tried by a judge whether with or without a jury; (Amended 21 of 2001 s. 48)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: from a determination, judgment, order or decision of the Court of First Instance referred to in section 22(1)(c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484). (Added 21 of 2001 s. 48. Amended 13 of 2021 s. 30; 14 of 2021 s. 471; 8 of 2022 s. 15)

subsection.content: Rules of court made under section 54 may provide for orders or judgments of any prescribed description to be treated for any prescribed purpose connected with appeals to the Court of Appeal as final or as interlocutory. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 10) [cf. 1981 c. 54 s. 60 U.K.]

No appeal shall lie from a decision of the Court of Appeal as to whether a judgment or order is, for any purpose connected with an appeal to that court, final or interlocutory. (Added 52 of 1987 s. 10)

section.name: s14AA
section.heading: Leave to appeal required for interlocutory appeals

subsection.content: Except as provided by rules of court, no appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from an interlocutory judgment or order of the Court of First Instance in any civil cause or matter unless leave to appeal has been granted by the Court of First Instance or the Court of Appeal.
Rules of court may specify a judgment or order of any prescribed description to which subsection (1) does not apply and accordingly an appeal lies as of right from the judgment or order.

subsection.leadIn: Leave to appeal for the purpose of subsection (1) may be granted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a particular issue arising out of the interlocutory judgment or order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as the court hearing the application for leave considers necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: Leave to appeal for the purpose of subsection (1) shall not be granted unless the court hearing the application for leave is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the appeal should be heard.

subsection.content: This section does not apply in relation to an interlocutory judgment or order of the Court of First Instance made before the commencement# of this section.

section.name: s14AB
section.heading: Decision on leave to appeal final
section.content: No appeal lies from a decision of the Court of Appeal as to whether or not leave to appeal to it should be granted.

section.name: s14A
section.heading: Appeal from order on application for judicial review in criminal cause or matter
section.text: An appeal shall lie to the Court of Appeal from a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance given or made on an application for judicial review referred to in section 21K(1) and relating to a criminal cause or matter.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Application for new trial

subsection.content: Where any cause or matter or any issue in any cause or matter has been tried in the Court of First Instance, any application for a new trial thereof, or to set aside a verdict, finding or judgment therein, shall be heard and determined by the Court of Appeal.
Nothing in this section shall alter the practice in bankruptcy.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Law and equity to be administered in High Court

subsection.content: The Court of Appeal and the Court of First Instance, when exercising jurisdiction in any civil cause or matter, shall continue to administer law and equity on the basis that, wherever there is any conflict or variance between the rules of equity and the rules of the common law with reference to the same matter, the rules of equity shall prevail.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of Appeal and the Court of First Instance shall give the same effect as hitherto—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to all equitable estates, titles, rights, reliefs, defences and counterclaims, and to all equitable duties and liabilities; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject thereto, to all legal claims and demands and all estates, titles, rights, duties, obligations, and liabilities existing by the common law or by any custom or created by any Ordinance,

subsection.continued: and shall so exercise its jurisdiction in every cause or matter before it as to secure that, as far as possible, all matters in dispute between the parties are completely and finally determined, and all multiplicity of legal proceedings with respect to any of those matters is avoided.

subsection.content: Nothing in this Ordinance shall affect the power of the Court of Appeal or the Court of First Instance to stay any proceedings before it, where it thinks fit to do so, either of its own motion or on the application of any person, whether or not a party to the proceedings.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Power to award damages as well as, or in substitution for, injunction or specific performance
section.text: Where the Court of Appeal or the Court of First Instance has jurisdiction to entertain an application for an injunction or specific performance, it may award damages in addition to, or in substitution for, an injunction or specific performance.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Power of Court of First Instance to impose charging order

subsection.content: Where, under a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance, a person (in this section and in sections 20A and 20B referred to as the debtor) is required to pay a sum of money to another person (in this section and in section 20A referred to as the creditor) then, for the purpose of enforcing that judgment or order, the Court of First Instance may make an order imposing on any such property of the debtor as may be specified in the order a charge for securing the payment of any money due or to become due under the judgment or order. (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 13)

An order under subsection (1) is referred to in this Ordinance as a
charging order. (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether to make a charging order the Court of First Instance shall consider all the circumstances of the case and, in particular, any evidence before it as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal circumstances of the debtor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether any other creditor of the debtor would be likely to be unduly prejudiced by the making of the order. (Replaced 52 of 1987 s. 13)

subsection.content: This section shall apply to a judgment, order, decree or award however called of any court or arbitrator or umpire, including any foreign court or foreign arbitrator or umpire, which is or has become enforceable, whether wholly or to a limited extent, as it applies to a judgment or order of the Court of First Instance. (Amended 17 of 2010 s. 112)

section.name: s20A
section.heading: Property which may be charged

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), a charge may be imposed by a charging order only on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: an interest held by the debtor beneficially—

subparagraph.content: in any asset of a kind mentioned in subsection (2) or
under any trust; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: an interest held by a person as trustee of a trust (in this paragraph referred to as the trust), if the interest is in an asset of a kind mentioned in subsection (2) or is an interest under another trust and—

subparagraph.content: the judgment or order in respect of which a charge is to be imposed was made against that person as trustee of the trust;
the whole beneficial interest under the trust is held by the debtor unencumbered and for his own benefit; or

in a case where there are 2 or more debtors all of whom are liable to the creditor for the same debt, they together hold the whole beneficial interest under the trust unencumbered and for their own benefit.

subsection.leadIn: The assets referred to in subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: securities of any of the following kinds—

subparagraph.content: Government stock;
stock of any body incorporated in Hong Kong;
units of any unit trust in respect of which a register of the unit holders is kept at any place within Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: funds in court.

subsection.content: In any case where a charge is imposed by a charging order on any interest in an asset of a kind mentioned in subsection (2)(b) or (c), the Court of First Instance may provide for the charge to extend to any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of the asset. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: dividend (派息) includes any distribution in respect of any unit of a unit trust; [cf. 1979 c. 53 s. 6 U.K.]

stock (證券) includes shares, debentures, loan stocks, funds, bonds, notes, any other securities issued by the body concerned, whether or not constituting a charge on the assets of that body and any rights or options to subscribe for or be allotted any of the foregoing; and

unit trust (單位信託) means any trust established for the purpose, or having the effect, of providing, for persons having funds available for investment, facilities for the participation by them, as beneficiaries under the trust, in any profits or income arising from the acquisition, holding, management or disposal of any property whatsoever.

section.name: s20B
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to sections 20 and 20A

subsection.content: A charging order may be made either absolutely or subject to conditions as to notifying the debtor or as to the time when the charge is to become enforceable, or as to other matters.
The Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128) shall apply in relation to charging orders as it applies in relation to other orders or writs issued or made for the purpose of enforcing judgments.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, a charge imposed by a charging order shall have the like effect and shall be enforceable in the same courts and in the same manner as an equitable charge created by the debtor by writing under his hand.

The Court of First Instance may at any time, on the application of the debtor or of any person interested in any property to which the order relates, make an order discharging or varying the charging order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

In the case of a charging order registered pursuant to the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128), if an order under subsection (4) discharging the charging order is made, the Land Registrar shall on the filing with him of a memorial and an office copy of such order, enter a discharge of such charging order on the register, and may issue certificates of such entry. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

section.name: s21
section.heading: Attachment of debts

subsection.leadIn: A sum standing to the credit of a person in a deposit account in an authorized financial institution shall, for the purposes of the jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance to attach debts for the purpose of satisfying judgments or orders for the payment of money, be deemed to be a sum due or accruing to that person and, subject to rules of court, shall be attachable accordingly, notwithstanding that any of the following conditions applicable to the account, that is to say— (Amended 52 of 1987 s. 15; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any condition that notice is required before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any condition that a personal application must be made before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any condition that a deposit book must be produced before any money is withdrawn;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any condition that a receipt for money deposited must be produced before any money is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other condition prescribed by rules of court,

subsection.continued: has not been satisfied.

subsection.def: In this section authorized financial institution (認可金融機構) means an authorized institution within the meaning of section 2 of the Banking Ordinance (Cap. 155). (Added 52 of 1987 s. 15. Amended 49 of 1995 s. 53)

section.name: s21A
section.heading: No arrest or imprisonment without order

subsection.content: Subject to section 21B, a person shall not be arrested or imprisoned to enforce, secure or pursue a civil claim for the payment of money or damages except under an order of Court; and the Court shall have jurisdiction to make such an order for arrest or imprisonment only to enforce, secure or pursue a judgment for the payment of a specified sum of money.
An order for imprisonment under subsection (1) shall be for a period not exceeding 3 months.
The period mentioned in subsection (2) may be amended by resolution of the Legislative Council.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The Court may, on application, discharge, vary or suspend an order for arrest or imprisonment made under this section, either absolutely or subject to such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The Court may make an order for arrest or imprisonment under this section subject to such conditions as it thinks fit, including conditions as to the time and place of execution of the order and the condition that the judgment debtor be released on the payment of the judgment debt and costs, the provision of security by him or on his behalf or on the surrender of his travel documents.

subsection.def: In this section, Court (法庭) includes the Registrar or any Master. (Amended 52 of 1987 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: This section shall not affect any jurisdiction of the Court to make orders of committal in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contempt of court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disobedience of a judgment or order of the Court.

section.name: s21B
section.heading: Prohibition on debtor leaving Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall have jurisdiction to make an order prohibiting a person from leaving Hong Kong (a prohibition order) to facilitate the enforcement, securing or pursuance of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judgment against that person for the payment of a specified sum of money;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a judgment or order against that person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the payment of an amount to be assessed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: requiring him to deliver any property or perform any other act; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a civil claim (other than a judgment)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the payment of money or damages; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for the delivery of any property or the performance of any other act.

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall not make an order under subsection (1)(b) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person against whom the order is sought is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by reason of paragraph (a), satisfaction of the judgment or order is likely to be obstructed or delayed.

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall not make an order under subsection (1)(c) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a good cause of action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person against whom the order is sought—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: incurred the alleged liability, which is the subject of the claim, in Hong Kong while he was present in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: carries on business in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is ordinarily resident in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that person is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: by reason of paragraph (c), any judgment that may be given against that person is likely to be obstructed or delayed.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The Court may, on application, discharge a prohibition order, either absolutely or subject to such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The Court may make a prohibition order subject to such conditions as it thinks fit, including the condition that the order shall have no effect if the judgment debtor or person against whom the claim is made satisfies the judgment or the claim or provides such security as the Court may order.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: An order under subsection (1) shall lapse—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on the expiry of one month but the Court may, on the application of the judgment creditor or claimant, extend or renew the order for a period which does not exceed, with the initial period of one month and any other period of extension or renewal, 3 months; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on the service upon the Director of Immigration and the filing with the Registrar of a notice by the judgment creditor or claimant advising that the order is no longer required.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The judgment creditor or claimant shall serve and file the notice mentioned in paragraph (a)(ii) as soon as reasonably possible after the order is no longer required.

subsection.content: A copy of an order under subsection (1) and any other order ancillary thereto shall be served on the Director of Immigration, the Commissioner of Police and, if he can be found, the judgment debtor or person against whom the claim is made.

Where the Court makes an order under subsection (1) prohibiting a person from leaving Hong Kong, any person who, having been served with a copy of the order or otherwise informed of its effect, attempts to leave Hong Kong in contravention of that order may be arrested by any immigration officer, police officer or bailiff.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: A person arrested under subsection (7) shall be brought before the Court before the expiry of the day after the day of arrest and the Court may—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
iii
subparagraph.content: in any case, make an order discharging that person from arrest either absolutely or upon compliance with such conditions as the Court thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Section 71 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall not apply to this subsection.

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration shall not be liable for any failure to prevent any person against whom an order is made under this section from leaving Hong Kong.

subsection.def: In this section, Court (法院、法庭) includes the Registrar or any Master. (Amended 52 of 1987 s. 17)

subsection.content: The form of order under this section may be prescribed by rules of court.

section.name: s21C
section.heading: Effect of writs of execution against goods

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a writ of fieri facias or other writ of execution against goods issued from the Court of First Instance shall bind the property in the goods of the execution debtor as from the time when the writ is delivered to the bailiff to be executed. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

A writ of a kind referred to in subsection (1) shall not prejudice the title to any goods of the execution debtor acquired by a person in good faith and for valuable consideration unless he had, at the time when he acquired his title, notice that that writ or any other such writ by virtue of which the goods of the execution debtor might be seized or attached had been delivered to and remained unexecuted in the hands of the bailiff.

For the better manifestation of the time mentioned in subsection (1), it shall be the duty of the bailiff (without fee) on receipt of any such writ as is there mentioned to endorse on its back the hour, day, month and year when he received it.

subsection.leadIn: In this section and in section 21D—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
d
paragraph.content: an act shall be treated as done in good faith if it is in fact done honestly, whether it is done negligently or not.

section.name: s21D
section.heading: Sale of property in execution of judgment

content.leadIn: The following property is liable to attachment and sale in execution of a judgment, namely, land, goods, money, bank notes, cheques, bills of exchange, promissory notes, Government stock, bonds, or other securities for money, debts, shares in the capital or joint stock of any company or corporation, (other than a private company within the meaning of section 11 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622)) and all other property whatsoever, whether movable or immovable, belonging to the judgment debtor, and whether the same is held in his own name or by another person in trust for him or on his behalf: (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)
content.proviso: Provided that the following property shall not be so liable, namely, the tools (if any) of the trade of the judgment debtor and the necessary wearing apparel and bedding of him and his family dependent on and residing with him, to a value, inclusive of tools and apparel and bedding, not exceeding $10,000 in the whole.

content.leadIn: Where any goods in the possession of an execution debtor at the time of seizure by the bailiff charged with the enforcement of a writ, warrant or other process of execution, are sold by such bailiff without any claim having been made to them, the purchaser of the goods so sold shall, subject to subsection (3), acquire a good title to such goods and no person shall be entitled to recover against the bailiff, or anyone lawfully acting under his authority, except as provided by section 46 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6), for any sale of such goods or for paying over the proceeds thereof prior to the receipt of a claim to the said goods, unless it is proved that the person from whom recovery is sought had notice or might by making reasonable inquiry have ascertained that the goods were not the property of the execution debtor:
content.proviso: Provided that nothing in this subsection shall affect the right of any claimant who may prove that at the time of sale he had title to any goods so seized and sold to any remedy to which he may be entitled against any person other than such bailiff or purchaser as aforesaid.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding the preceding provisions of this section the Court may, subject to rules of court, set aside the sale of any immovable property in execution of a judgment on the ground of material irregularity in the conduct of the sale.

section.name: s21E
section.heading: Enforcement of fines and forfeited recognizances

subsection.content: Payment of a fine imposed, or sum due under a recognizance forfeited, by the Court of Appeal in its civil jurisdiction or by the Court of First Instance may be enforced upon the order of the Court in like manner as a judgment of the Court of First Instance for the payment of money.

subsection.leadIn: Where payment of a fine or other sum falls to be enforced upon an order of the Court of Appeal in its civil jurisdiction or of the Court of First Instance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court shall, if the fine or other sum is not paid in full forthwith or within such time as the Court may allow, certify to the Registrar the sum payable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall thereupon proceed to enforce payment of that sum as if it were due to him as a judgment debt.

subsection.def: In this section, fine (罰款) includes a penalty imposed in civil proceedings.

section.name: s21F
section.heading: Relief against forfeiture by action for non-payment of rent

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1A), this section has effect where a lessor is proceeding by action in the Court of First Instance to enforce against a lessee a right of re-entry or forfeiture in respect of any land for non-payment of rent. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 32 of 2002 s. 40)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Where during the term of a lease the application of this section has prevented a lessor from enforcing against a lessee a right mentioned in subsection (1), then during that term this section shall not be applicable again to prevent the lessor from exercising that right against the lessee unless the Court is satisfied that there is good cause why this section should apply in favour of the lessee. (Added 32 of 2002 s. 40)

If, within the time prescribed by rules of court for acknowledging service of the writ by which the action was commenced, the lessee pays into court all the rent in arrear and the costs of the action, the action shall cease, and the lessee shall hold the land according to the lease without any new lease.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the action does not cease under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court at the trial is satisfied that the lessor is entitled to enforce the right of re-entry or forfeiture,

subsection.continued: the Court shall order possession of the land to be given to the lessor at the expiration of such period, but not being less than 7 days from the date of the order, as the Court thinks fit, unless within that period the lessee pays into court all the rent in arrear and such sum as the Court shall direct on account of the costs of the action. (Amended 32 of 2002 s. 40)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: The Secretary for Development may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend the number of days specified in subsection (3) by substituting another number therefor. (Added 32 of 2002 s. 40. Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)
The Court may extend the period specified under subsection (3) at any time before possession of the land is recovered in pursuance of the order under that subsection.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the period specified in the order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within that period as extended under subsection (4),

subsection.continued: the lessee pays into court—

paragraph.content: all the rent in arrear; and
the sum directed to be paid on account of the costs of the action,

subsection.continued: he shall hold the land according to the lease without any new lease.
